By “free speech”, I simply mean that which matches the law. 

I am against censorship that goes far beyond the law. 

If people want less free speech, they will ask government to pass laws to that effect.

Therefore, going beyond the law is contrary to the will of the people.

text:
@24_7TeslaNews @Teslarati @ResidentSponge Current generation Neuralinks can help to some degree, but an advanced case of Alzheimers often involves macro degeneration of the brain. 

However, Neuralinks should theoretically be able restore almost any functionality lost due *localized* brain damage from stroke or injury.

text:
@SamTwits @Erdayastronaut @PPathole @vincent13031925 Long chain hydrocarbons, like kerosene, have excellent volumetric energy density, but what you really want for rockets is best way to bind hydrogen, which is CH4. 

Also, easy to make & store CH4+O2 from CO2+H2O, which are abundant on Mars.
name: Musk

text: @truth_tesla @LimitingThe Our new cell is 46mm diameter with steel shell & even that was huge challenge for propagation resistance
name: Musk

text:
@truth_tesla @LimitingThe Yes. 

Physics of large cells means distance from cooling loop to center of cell is high, so harder to prevent hotspots.

Then, pressure & heat released from large cell in weak bag make it impossible to stop whole pack from burning.

Pretty basic.
name: Musk

name: Musk

@Erdayastronaut @Caspar_Stanley No, bottom static aero pushes engine section back, counteracting Starship’s low center of mass on reentry caused by the engine section.

text:
@Erdayastronaut Btw, there’s a slight error with forward flap design. Moving section is needed for control, but passive section is counter-productive, as it pushes nose backwards. 

New design rotates fwd flaps more to leeward & further forward to improve moment arm. Maybe ~120 deg apart.

text: Civil rights pioneers, teachers, artists, lawyers, homemakers, and so many more. I’m proud to give a home to each one of these  stories at Oprah Daily and share them with you on this #Juneteenth and beyond.
name: Oprah

text: Their experiences and wisdom can lead us to a better future if we’re open to receive it. What makes their stories even more poignant, is that young Black journalists and photographers captured their words and images in a spectrum of Black excellence.
name: Oprah

text: I love that Juneteenth is now an official federal holiday. A time to honor our past and those who’ve forged a path to our present. Which is why I’m excited to present #LiftEveryVoice, a collection of powerful interviews with a highly regarded older generation of Black Americans. https://t.co/oPHUvelNJx
name: Oprah

text: RT @AppleTV : In this special free episode of #TheMeYouCantSee, @Oprah and Prince Harry sit back down with the world’s top mental health experts to talk about where we go from here, and how to keep the conversation going. Watch it now on Apple TV+  https://t.co/Ry8gEvs894 https://t.co/c2HYpeS3xL
name: Oprah

text: Watch “The Me You Can’t See: A Path Forward,” now available for FREE on @appletv+: https://t.co/vyO76itmCo
name: Oprah

text: If you finished watching my new docuseries #TheMeYouCantSee, you might be thinking “Now, what can I do?” My fellow co-producer Prince Harry and I sat back down with some of the world’s top mental health experts to discuss where we can all go from here. https://t.co/8qRIrwIh0h
name: Oprah

text: RT @OprahDaily : Oprah and Prince Harry Are Hosting a Town Hall Inspired by "The Me You Can't See" https://t.co/k6odBlXYgT
name: Oprah

text:
Thank you, Fawzi and Dr. Essam. I see you. Watch Fawzi’s story with Dr. Essam on #TheMeYouCantSee, available now on @AppleTV+: 
https://t.co/cgPvZazbtf
name: Oprah

text: It’s his job to help connect the current lives of young children to the souls and minds they left behind. And that’s what he’s trying to help Fawzi do: Process the trauma, find the good memories, and transform this traumatic experience into something good.
name: Oprah

text: Enter Dr. @essamdaod, a child psychiatrist working with kids of Syrian refugees with his international aid organization @HumanityCrew. He believes that when you escape your troubled home, it’s not only your body that suffers and is in need of a doctor, but also your mind. https://t.co/ixR4XIh5Z9
name: Oprah

text: Now, he doesn’t like to think about it because it makes him cry, and he thinks the solution is to try and forget his brother. He’s experiencing trauma, but he’s too young to even know it...let alone have the tools to process it.
name: Oprah

text: He’s experienced a lot in his 11 years on Earth, but the most traumatic experience was his brother being killed in a playground bombing. Fawzi and his mother ran to look for his brother when they found out but he had been blown to pieces.
name: Oprah

text: The Me You Can’t See: Fawzi, suffering from childhood trauma. After trying to flee war-filled Syria three times by boat, Fawzi finally made it to a remote refugee camp in Greece.
name: Oprah

text: The Me You Can See: Fawzi, an 11-year-old who loves to play with his friends. https://t.co/gySlk8Rok4
name: Oprah

text: RT @RealHughJackman : I recommend, so highly, the new @AppleTV series from @Oprah and #PrinceHarry called #TheMeYouCantSee. Mental health is all too often met with a stigma. This needs to change. Right now. And to @VancityReynolds, my brother, I couldn’t be more proud and inspired by your honesty. https://t.co/5aBPgwdxYb
name: Oprah

text: RT @DEADLINE : Oprah Winfrey & Prince Harry To Host ‘The Me You Can’t See’ Follow-Up Town Hall Conversation On Apple https://t.co/o1v8C8VmGX
name: Oprah

text:
Watch Rashad’s story on #TheMeYouCantSee, now available on @AppleTV+: 
https://t.co/cgPvZazbtf
name: Oprah

text: Now, he’s realized that in order to finally be free, he has to rip the mask off—so he’s going to therapy, no matter how hard it may be. Thank you, Rashad. I see you.
name: Oprah

text: You go to church, take it to God, and everything will be just fine. But dealing with all of his pain on his own made him lose his passion for cooking; to this day, he can’t even watch his episode of Chopped because he was in so much internal pain while filming the show.
name: Oprah

text: He was taught to push it all down, put on a mask, smile, and fake it, even when he was feeling completely broken inside. Because he says in much of the Black community, therapy is taboo, speaking to a therapist was out of the question.
name: Oprah

text: The Me You Can’t See: Rashad, living with depression and anxiety. Rashad says he’s seen a lot of things in his life, from his house being raided as a kid to his dad going to jail—and all that childhood trauma led him to a place of depression. https://t.co/B5aVF6Pf5i
name: Oprah

text: The Me You Can See: Chef Rashad Armstead, a successful chef and a winner of the Food Network show #Chopped. https://t.co/ETZ4gGhmmH
name: Oprah

text: RT @jayshetty : I had the pleasure of interviewing @oprah & @dbperry on the podcast this week. Listen to our FULL talk here: https://t.co/EeJ1eaQqpQ https://t.co/ZN3rRpnwmu
name: Oprah

text: There’s so much more to see in our stories. When we widen the screen to widen our view, we can broaden the spectrum of the images we see, the stories we tell, & the people we understand. Fully. Join us tonight at 8|7c on @OWNTV for #WidenTheScreen, presented by @ProcterGamble. https://t.co/Wh6yI607D7
name: Oprah

text:
RT @OWNTV : A year later... Our grief is not behind us, but our stories have helped us look ahead. Our fight has not ended, but our stories have the power to change the world. 

#OurStories continue ✊🏾 https://t.co/iHacPYe9cJ
name: Oprah

text:
A year ago today we didn’t know his name, but now it’s forever etched in our consciousness: #GeorgeFloyd. 

(🎨: @N_du_Time for @OprahDaily) https://t.co/I0zpkuqGUy
name: Oprah

text: Watch Ginny’s story on #TheMeYouCantSee, now available on @appleTV+: https://t.co/cgPvZazbtf
name: Oprah

text: It wasn’t until she got stuck in a viscous cycle of cleaning where she only slept for 2 hours in 3 days that she experienced a mental breakdown—& decided to seek help. She says that coming out with her OCD struggles is helping her understand it more. Thank you, Ginny. I see you.
name: Oprah

text: She’ll clean her room until 5 AM, wash her hands in a specific pattern for an extended period of time, or go through multiple toothbrushes during one teeth-cleaning session.
name: Oprah

text: There are various types of OCD, but Ginny’s specifically manifests in a fear of contamination. The feeling of disgust is so unpleasant and intolerable that it feels like it’ll last forever, so she tries to get rid of that uncomfortable feeling.
name: Oprah

text: The Me You Can’t See: Ginny Fuchs, living with OCD. In middle school, Ginny went to seek inpatient treatment for her anorexia. It was there that doctors discovered what was causing her eating disorder: An obsessive compulsive disorder. https://t.co/GiazoyIrRF
name: Oprah

text: The Me You Can See: @GinnyFuchsUSA, the #3 ranked boxer in the world, on her way to this year’s Olympics. https://t.co/kYiRy1Wu8w
name: Oprah

text: Widen The Screen: A Fuller View of Black Life, presented by @ProcterGamble, airs this Tuesday 5/25 at 8|7c on @OWNTV. We’ll be celebrating Black stories and featuring short films and new content by Black creators—hope to see y’all there! #WidenTheScreen https://t.co/aGFJKrDz97
name: Oprah

text:
Watch Stefani’s story on #TheMeYouCantSee, now available on @AppleTV+: 
https://t.co/cgPvZazbtf
name: Oprah

text: She’s learned to pull herself out of dark places with the help of doctors, medicine, and coping mechanisms—and happened to win an Oscar during that process. Now, instead of locking away that experience, she’s trying to give back by sharing it. Thank you, Stefani. I see you.
name: Oprah

text: Through the years, this trauma remained unprocessed, resulting in Stefani cutting herself, experiencing a psychotic break, and finally being diagnosed with PTSD after going to the hospital for chronic pain.
name: Oprah

text: The Me You Can’t See: Stefani Germanotta. While getting her start in the music industry at 19, Stefani was told by a producer to take off her clothes and threatened to have her music burned when she didn’t comply. She was raped. https://t.co/SpZXHCudl7
name: Oprah

text: The Me You Can See: @ladygaga winning an Oscar in 2019. https://t.co/J4h03xNI1r
name: Oprah

text: @HumanityCrew @AppleTV Thank you for saving Lives.🙏🏾
name: Oprah

text: @annedellahines This alone makes all the challenges of filming and finishing this series during Covid worth it. I do hope you’re feeling better today. Tho I realize the grief comes in waves. Thank you and your husband for watching.
name: Oprah

text: RT @Essence : EXCLUSIVE: Oprah and Prince Harry are joining forces to free people from the shame and stigma of mental heath crisis. The pair spoke with, Lifestyle Director, Charli Penn, about their new project, grief, and getting through. #ESSENCE https://t.co/sHfdQCSSuq
name: Oprah

text:
RT @NPRKelly : Got to talk with @Oprah and Prince Harry about being business partners & the stories they wanted to tell about how we ALL struggle with mental health, in their new documentary series, "The Me You Can't See.”
https://t.co/yjxctw1lb8
name: Oprah

text: RT @AppleNews : In a special Mental Health Awareness Month edition of Apple News Spotlight, Prince Harry and @Oprah hand-selected a reading list to help guide meaningful conversations around mental health and emotional well-being. https://t.co/8omcbcYp8m https://t.co/BT183WWCcr
name: Oprah

text: Watch our story on #TheMeYouCantSee, available now on @AppleTV+: https://t.co/cgPvZazbtf
name: Oprah

text: My 17-year relationship with Alex has caused me to look at mental health in a very different way than I had approached it before. I am very proud of her for sharing her truth, creating a better life for herself, and rising to her best self every single day.
name: Oprah

text: Because of her traumatic upbringing, Alex was diagnosed with PTSD, something I was not equipped to handle. I’ve tried in many ways to help her, but I know now that PTSD is not something that just goes away; it's a lifelong journey, and we’re both learning.
name: Oprah

text: All she needed was someone to believe in her, so I gave her my number and a scholarship—and we’ve been in each other’s lives ever since. What I didn’t know then was that I was stepping into something I did not understand.
name: Oprah

text: The Me You Can’t See: Me and Alex. Many people don't remember that one of the people featured in that episode was a homeless girl by the name of Alex. In spite of everything that life had thrown her way, she still persevered and finished school. https://t.co/BaAMFbVLIt
name: Oprah

text: The Me You Can See: Me giving away cars. For over 17 years, that famous episode of me shouting “You get a car!” to deserving people in my studio audience has followed me. Videos, gifs, memes—you name it, I’ve seen it. https://t.co/nMA79JYnQY
name: Oprah

text: @introvertnfj Agree. Hardest to edit also.
name: Oprah

text: @Bella_Mari4 @AppleNews @AppleTV Your realization alone was reason enough to do the series. I hope you thrive with the help.🙏🏾
name: Oprah

text:

text: I believe that America’s Food Fund will be a powerful way to make a difference for our neighbors in need and am committing $1 million to this fund to support those facing food insecurity.
name: Oprah

text: I was struck by the work these organizations are doing and while everyone’s priority right now is to stay safer at home, I know there are many of us looking for ways to help.
name: Oprah

text: Watch my free Apple TV conversation with him here: https://t.co/n7L6drnpcV

text: Mr. Anthony Ray Hinton spent 30 years on death row for a crime he did not commit until he was exonerated. I checked in to see how he was coping with confinement. Surprisingly, he’s doing fine (and safer) at home and he even had some words of wisdom for all of us. https://t.co/aE8iinhgXH
name: Oprah

text: Like millions of people all over the world, I've been staying safer at home for over a week now. I know a lot of people are feeling stressed, overwhelmed, & uncertain. Bc of that, I want to offer some hope & gather thought leaders & people going through it to add some perspective
name: Oprah

text: Just got a phone call that my name is trending. And being trolled for some awful FAKE thing. It’s NOT TRUE. Haven’t been raided, or arrested. Just sanitizing and self distancing with the rest of the world. Stay safe everybody.🙏🏾
name: Oprah

text: RT @ulalaunch : We've had a successful staging on the #AtlasV. Separation of the first stage and ignition of the Dual Engine Centaur upper stage has occurred  off the coast of the Carolinas. Both engines are up and running. Live coverage available here: https://t.co/VIynIdVS23
name: NASA

text: RT @ulalaunch : #AtlasV's main engine has completed its deep throttling, coming out of the throttle bucket, after easing the rocket through the region of maximum aerodynamic stress. The vehicle has gone transonic as both SRBs continue to fire. Watch the launch live: https://t.co/VIynIdVS23
name: NASA

text: RT @ulalaunch : #Starliner is riding 1.6 million pounds of thrust from #AtlasV to take aim on the @Space_Station for docking in 24 hours. Houston has assumed control as the rocket rolls to a northeasterly heading in pursuit of ISS, currently 262 miles above the North Atlantic approaching Europe.
name: NASA

text: @haasteinn Plants on the Moon would likely be growing in a habitat shared with humans, so the atmosphere, temp., and lighting could be similar to how they were grown in the Florida lab. But one day they could have their own habitat; plants tend to do well in low-pressure atmospheres.
name: NASA

text: @StarshipShuffle @UF @NASASpaceSci The areas of the Moon around the Apollo 11, 12 and 17 sites are mostly of crushed basalt rocks. It's typically not called “soil” as it doesn't have the hallmarks of Earth soil–organic material & life. The minute you grow a plant in it, regolith essentially becomes “soil." https://t.co/NylnrEwINX
name: NASA

text:
Got questions about the black hole at the center of our Milky Way Galaxy (and how it interacts with the space around it)?

name: NASA

text:

Ask @UF and @NASAMoon experts about their groundbreaking experiment, and what it means for future astronauts. https://t.co/0UGzCTvoo7
name: NASA

text:
For the first time ever, scientists have grown plants in lunar soil.

This @UF and @NASASpaceSci experiment using Apollo Moon samples could shape the future of sustainable astronaut missions to deep space. Dig into the story: https://t.co/ZtUvowKi8e https://t.co/PWGzev7lmN
name: NASA

text: @annoyingcr Yes! When @NASAWebb begins its first science operations this summer, it will join the stellar network of observatories capable of peering into the hearts of galaxies to study the swirling black holes at their centers. We. can't. wait.
name: NASA

text:
@e_standge It looks similar, but you're looking at the first image ever taken of the black hole at the center of our galaxy. It's 4 million times more massive than the Sun. 

In comparison, the M87 galaxy's black hole (image released in 2019), is several billion times the mass of the Sun.
name: NASA

text:
Have you seen the picture of the black hole at the center of our galaxy?
 
The image of Sagittarius A* (inset) was taken by @EHTelescope. Now see it in context with support from our @ChandraXray, Swift and NuSTAR observatories. Here's what the colors mean: https://t.co/Qkt3Qu3v1r https://t.co/BONW7QZhsu
name: NASA

text: Congratulations to the @ehtelescope team on capturing the first image of Sagittarius A*, the black hole at the center of our galaxy! https://t.co/unviRGjZEe

text: @zacallier One is much closer! They only appear to overlap because of a chance alignment. This alignment gives astronomers an opportunity: by measuring how dust in the foreground galaxy affects starlight from the background galaxy, they can map dust in the foreground galaxy’s spiral arms.
name: NASA

text: @leoalbuq1 Great question! Most lunar samples brought back to Earth by Apollo astronauts have been opened and studied. But some samples collected on the Apollo 15, 16 & 17 missions were kept unopened and pristine, so they could be analyzed with more advanced technologies available today.
name: NASA

text:
Good things come to those who wait.

Teams will begin tapping one of the last unopened Moon rock samples acquired during Apollo 17, around 50 years ago. The goal is to learn more about the lunar surface in anticipation of upcoming @NASAArtemis missions: https://t.co/q6P2KpSSvp https://t.co/hRN5FRnC4j
name: NASA

text: @iishmalkhan Yes, our future mission Dragonfly will send an eight-bladed rotorcraft that flies like a drone to Titan. Dragonfly will study this ocean world's atmospheric and surface properties, subsurface ocean and liquid reservoirs, and complex carbon-rich chemistry: https://t.co/FnIocM0jcF
name: NASA

text:
Twin galaxies? Look again 👀

From the perspective of our orbiting @NASAHubble telescope, these two galaxies in the Virgo constellation appear side-by-side... but they're actually more than 150 million light-years apart: https://t.co/0VfGwYiHvF https://t.co/OMoDwbjaaa
name: NASA

text:

text: @bfcultras Planets (typically) don’t fall into their star due to conservation of angular momentum. Their orbital motion around a star balances gravitational tugs. But some planets have unstable orbits, and do eventually fall into their stars! Note: The TRAPPIST-1 planets have stable orbits.
name: NASA

text: @piratefalcon325 @NASAWebb @NASAAstrobio Red dwarfs are truly horrible when they're young, bathing any potential planets in harmful radiation that could influence atmospheric chemistry and possibly strip off these fledgling planets' atmospheres. We're trying to better understand the possible effects of older red dwarfs.
name: NASA

text: @AshishR81366662 We know 3 of them are in the habitable zone — the right orbital distance to be warm enough for liquid water to exist on their surfaces. Astronomers will use @NASAWebb to look for signs of an atmosphere, the next step to finding out if life could survive: https://t.co/THNX8GjW3f
name: NASA

text: @UDAYKIR94731329 Artemis I will be the 1st integrated test of our @NASA_Orion crew module, @NASA_SLS rocket, and @NASAKennedy's ground systems. It'll send Orion on a journey around the Moon & assure its safe entry, descent, splashdown, and recovery on its return to Earth: https://t.co/f35LOCFLF7
name: NASA

text: @BJones79 Don't worry! DART can't change the orbit in a way that would send the asteroid closer to Earth. All it will do is slightly change the speed of the smaller asteroid, which will stay in orbit around the larger asteroid, as our expert explained here: https://t.co/WfV4SKLI7A
name: NASA

text: @migzcuad @NASAWebb Light can travel faster than we have the technology to. That said, @NASAWebb will be focusing on studying the atmospheres of these planets to determine which molecules and elements (maybe the building blocks of life!) exist there and what they indicate about the world. (2/2)
name: NASA

text: @migzcuad @NASAWebb It depends on how far away those planets are! For example, the Trappist system is only 39.4 light years away, so we would be seeing the light that left it 39+ years ago. That doesn't mean we could travel there easily or quickly. (1/2)
name: NASA

text: @JLCDhome2018 @NASAWebb What is special about this orbit is that it lets the telescope stay in line with the Earth as it moves around the Sun. This allows the satellite's large sunshield to protect the telescope from the light and heat of the Sun and Earth (and Moon): https://t.co/rww0hBX9Ej
name: NASA

text: @scottparnapy @NASAWebb The sunshield will allow the telescope to cool down to a temperature below 50 Kelvin (-370°F, or -223°C) by passively radiating its heat into space. @NASAWebb’s MIRI instrument uses a cryocooler to reach its significantly lower operating temperatures of -447°F (7 kelvins).
name: NASA

text: @JPMajor @NASAWebb Good things come to those who wait! In the meantime, just know we've got a lot of exciting science up ahead: https://t.co/8zPS6MetB4 #UnfoldTheUniverse
name: NASA

text: @_Crazycrit @NASAWebb As Webb is orbiting L2, it's also moving around the Sun. Since Webb can only point to roughly half the sky at any given moment because it can’t look in the direction of Earth & the Sun, this affords Webb access to the entire sky over the course of a year: https://t.co/Fv0KXtzKLS
name: NASA

text: @ianwalkerxx @NASAWebb After @NASAWebb reaches Lagrange point 2 in a few weeks, it will take ~5 months to cool down, align its mirrors & calibrate its instruments before the science begins: https://t.co/2RH2EXQX7a #UnfoldTheUniverse
name: NASA

text: @bricetune They have a much bigger cryogenic vacuum chamber at @NASA_Johnson that was used on the Apollo program and we tested our mirror and instruments there. The spacecraft (sunshield and bus) were built at Northrop Grumman and they were connected to the mirror/instruments there. (2/2)
name: NASA

text: @bricetune As big as the vacuum chamber at Goddard is, it isn't big enough for all of Webb! We did test our instrument module there, but after that we had to move the hardware to NASA Johnson. (1/2)
name: NASA

text: @MetaOracle @NASAWebb Webb can #UnfoldTheUniverse through the infrared spectrum and also has the ability to see a little bit into visible light. Since infrared and visible light are next to each other on the spectrum, @NASAWebb's vision extends just a little bit into the red portion of the visible.
name: NASA

text: LIVE: @NASAWebb has completed the final stage of spacecraft deployment to #UnfoldTheUniverse. Mission experts discuss today's major milestone.  https://t.co/u2c50P4G0Y
name: NASA

text: @skybits We do expect tiny micrometeorite impacts, and the telescope was designed and tested for this.The sunshield has special seams to limit micrometeorid damage. Testing showed that micrometeoroids have negligible effects on the telescope's beryllium mirrors: https://t.co/Jx1ThKYsPL
name: NASA

text:
Congratulations, @NASAWebb! You are fully deployed! 🥳

Stay tuned over the coming months as the space telescope reaches its destination of Lagrange point 2 and prepares to #UnfoldTheUniverse: https://t.co/qg6jmVRCsH
name: NASA

text: @zenmonk55 It is now over 74% of the way to its orbit at the second Lagrange point, or L2. You can follow in real time and see how far it has to go and its current speed on this timeline: https://t.co/DY7KqaAj8g
name: NASA

text: RT @nasahqphoto : Final wing is now deployed! Short celebration, but we’ve still got work to do. Engineers are working to latch the wing into place, a multi-hour process. When the final latch is secure, #NASAWebb will be fully unfolded in space. #UnfoldTheUniverse More 📷 https://t.co/n9v3La32ic https://t.co/Mng79UTPRT
name: NASA

text: @Jeetpriyodey1 The Universe is now about 13.8 billion years old. We'll see a period of the Universe's history we haven't seen before, which is about 200 million years after the Big Bang, when the first galaxies started forming. https://t.co/vkI0lNdZxx
name: NASA

text: @jamesdmoore614 @NASAHubble @NASAWebb Webb will observe the Ultra Deep Field in our 1st year of science operations. It'll take Webb less than a day to see deeper into the universe than Hubble saw in 2 weeks of staring! It will find tens of thousand of galaxies that are too red & too faint for Hubble to detect.
name: NASA

text: @PatBarr52364730 The telescope has four science instruments which cover near-infrared through mid-infrared wavelengths, from 0.6 microns up through 28 microns: https://t.co/3dK4AwKDiA
name: NASA

text: @WangnickS The sunshield has special seams to limit meteorite damage. Testing showed that micrometeoroids have negligible effects on the telescope's beryllium mirrors: https://t.co/Jx1ThKYsPL
name: NASA

text: @WangnickS Debris isn't an issue a million miles away where we will orbit L2, and space is big so impacts from larger objects (asteroids, meteors) won't be an issue. We do expect tiny micrometeorite impacts, and the telescope was designed and tested for this.
name: NASA

text: @CougerMom @NASAWebb’s mirrors are made of beryllium because it's stable across a a wide range of temperatures. They’re then coated in a thin layer of gold to improve the mirror's reflection of infrared light. Here's more info: https://t.co/6eUrI3tOFQ
name: NASA

text: @PatBarr52364730 The Near Infrared Camera (NIRCam), @NASAWebb's primary imager, will cover the infrared wavelength range 0.6 to 5 microns. It will detect light from the earliest stars and galaxies! Details here: https://t.co/iQ0D48wAHH
name: NASA

text: @JamesLundblad Webb’s instruments will provide wavelength coverage from 0.6 to 28 micrometers (or microns). The infrared part of the electromagnetic spectrum goes from about 0.75 microns to a few hundred microns. This means it will be able to see about 200 million years after the Big Bang.

text:
Shields up! @NASAWebb has completed the tensioning of its tennis-court-size sunshield.

This five-layered shade will protect the telescope from the heat of the Sun, Earth and Moon, helping it #UnfoldTheUniverse in infrared light. Details & next steps: https://t.co/m9eFc0ysib https://t.co/qF1UQV3cIY
name: NASA

text: @lsullivan 🤩 Your kindness makes the planets go 'round. Thank you for being aboard our journey to #UnfoldTheUniverse! https://t.co/Bnx7Q7Ribb
name: NASA

text:
RT @NASAWebb : This is it: we’ve just wrapped up one of the most challenging steps of our journey to #UnfoldTheUniverse.

With all five layers of sunshield tensioning complete, about 75% of our 344 single-point failures have been retired! https://t.co/P9jJhu7bJX
name: NASA

text: @nachtsmeer The layers, each as thin as a human hair, are made of Kapton, a tough, high-performance plastic. Every layer is coated with aluminum, & the sun-facing side of the two hottest layers also have a doped-silicon (or treated silicon) coating to reflect the sun's heat back into space.
name: NASA

text:
Why is @NASAWebb's sunshield shaped like a kite? In short, it's exactly the shape & size it needs to be.
 
The iconic profile lets the telescope tilt back and forth to observe more of the universe. Plus, it helps radiate heat from the sides. Take a look: https://t.co/YhpDZdWLb8 https://t.co/TjCXoFivq9
name: NASA

text: @JacksonBTT Splitting the sunshield into 5 layers allows heat to radiate out from between them, causing each successive layer to be cooler than the one below. The vacuum of space between each layer also acts as a great insulator. Learn more about the sunshield design: https://t.co/j1nRsAwHOL
name: NASA

text:
It's time: @NASAWebb is GO to begin tensioning its fifth and final sunshield layer, a major milestone for the telescope. Watch the live feed from mission control: https://t.co/aKiLInSCBP

#UnfoldTheUniverse https://t.co/w0dVvzVItH
name: NASA

text:

name: NASA

text:

text:

text:

text:

text: @Mahdi_Sororian With its current timeline, we're anticipating an end of January 2022 arrival at L2. Then, we'll have another ~5 months of preparations before it starts science operations. You can track where Webb is in its million-mile journey in real-time here: https://t.co/1odiCzuC6c
name: NASA

text: @dexterDMpearson Oort Cloud objects are far too faint, even for Webb, unless we get extremely lucky. Webb will look at a lot of other exciting and distant things, though! Check out its science goals here: https://t.co/ZgJOIZMu5y

text: Here it is: humanity’s final look at @NASAWebb as it heads into deep space to answer our biggest questions. Alone in the vastness of space, Webb will soon begin an approximately two-week process to deploy its antennas, mirrors, and sunshield. #UnfoldTheUniverse https://t.co/DErMXJhNQd

text: @Shilpaa30thakur Webb will look back 13.5 billion years at the first galaxies that formed about 200 million years after the Big Bang. We hope to get answers about the formation of the universe, but perhaps one of the most incredible things is that we don't yet know what it will discover!
name: NASA

text:

The Ariane 5 rocket is scheduled to roll out to the launchpad Dec. 23: https://t.co/SZE0Hb2VeK https://t.co/zjFhFYFpVl

text:
@zoomjockey Webb is traveling about a million miles away where it will orbit the Sun, so its sunshield can block any heat and radiation from not just the Sun, but also Earth. 

This ensures that it can see the infrared light from very faint and distant objects. More: https://t.co/G2Y0VHPIez
name: NASA

text:

Join us for a panoramic trip through Jezero Crater: https://t.co/eZTESCE59P https://t.co/jvLfKFh5vl

text: Why can you see the Moon during the day? Easy, because it’s there! It may seem odd to look up at the daytime sky and see the Moon but it’s perfectly natural. We break it down so you know when to look up. Follow more Moon science: https://t.co/reibVE3xRU https://t.co/fe9NcvQqKZ

text: @cachafaz46 Comet tails always point away from the Sun, no matter their direction of travel, because the heat and high-speed solar particles change the comet's ices to gases, blowing the dust and gas away. Here's more info: https://t.co/MEYlLAnCqW
name: NASA

text:
☄️ See comet come, see comet go. 

Only discovered in January 2021, Comet Leonard’s half-mile (1 km) mass of ice, rock, and space dust will make its closest pass of the Sun on Jan. 3, 2022 – a journey 40,000 years in the making: https://t.co/3KCslrjR5N https://t.co/oYLoDRAY8c
name: NASA

text:

text:
No matter where on Earth you are, it's time for the December solstice!

10:59am EST (15:59 UTC) marks the start of astronomical winter in the Northern Hemisphere—and the beginning of astronomical summer in the Southern Hemisphere. Here's what that means: https://t.co/ZAJQ8YFtVZ https://t.co/JCUB7OmFg9
name: NASA

text:
We don’t yet know what @NASAWebb will uncover. Will we get answers? Will we have more questions? One thing is certain: The story of us is a never-ending quest for knowledge.

As Carl Sagan said: “We can’t help it.” #UnfoldTheUniverse

@bbyylj @NASAWebb Webb is designed to have a mission lifetime of at least 5.5 years after launch, with the goal of a lifetime of 10+ years. That life is limited by the amount of fuel used for maintaining the orbit, and by proper functioning in orbit of the spacecraft.

@Steve70308170 @NASAWebb We chose Ariane in the early 2000s for a combination of reliability (it was the only launch vehicle that met NASA's requirements for launching a mission like Webb) and for the value it brings via our international partnership.

text: @3Bonanno @NASAPersevere Can and does! Both @NASAPersevere and @MarsCuriosity take selfies like this with cameras at the end of their robotic arms. text: The bedrock of Mars's Jezero Crater, across which @NASAPersevere has rolled for nearly 10 months, appears to have been formed from red-hot magma—possibly from a long-dormant Martian volcano: https://t.co/eZTESCE59P https://t.co/9FKcR6nXQd
name: NASA

text: @RGMarett We have yet to find conclusive evidence of liquid water on modern Mars, but long ago, yes! @MarsCuriosity found evidence of a flowing river of near pH neutral water on ancient Mars, somewhere between ankle- and hip-deep. https://t.co/ith7tRv8QI
name: NASA

text:
@lsullivan The universe's oldest galaxies are over 13 billion light-years away from Earth, which means that @NASAWebb will be looking over 13 billion years into the past when their light reaches our telescope! 

Check out our Webb FAQ for more: https://t.co/hXWukOH3ZZ
name: NASA

text:
@TommyTsue Webb will start cooling down once it's in space, and once it's cold enough, we'll need to fine-tune the alignment of the mirrors and calibrate the instruments.

We're expecting to begin routine science observations six months after launch! More info: https://t.co/Vhr1Qdic6k
name: NASA

text: Is there water on Mars? There sure is! It’s not exactly like water on Earth, but Martian H20 can tell us a lot about the planet’s distant past while potentially aiding explorers in the future. Mars scientist Eva Scheller explains. Get more Martian science: https://t.co/xyqltucdPM https://t.co/mC18XfiHzW
name: NASA

text: @T_R_Sullivan Nope! It has a a heat shield that can withstand up to 3,000 F (1,650 C), autonomy software to keep its instruments safe & cool, and a cooling system. Plus, the Sun's corona has an extremely high temperature but very low density. More details: https://t.co/MUyvZKEx33
name: NASA

text: @HarrietteSucher @NASASun Parker Solar Probe is named after Eugene Parker, one of the pioneers of sun science (https://t.co/nqMbhSvGt9)—so unfortunately not, though we still think he's pretty super!

text: @GlenMcclatchey To study the most distant objects in the universe, we must observe infrared light with a telescope & instruments optimized for this light. Webb's mirrors are coated with about a golf ball's mass of gold for this reason. Gold happens to reflect red & infrared light extremely well!
name: NASA

text: @annamarizii There isn't a real time simulation, but before the astronauts go to space, they practice spacewalks in mockup facilities on the ground and in our Neutral Buoyancy Lab. Spacewalk experts described the process of planning & training here: https://t.co/ww7eWIou9K
name: NASA

text: �� What a view! @AstroMarshburn catches a ride on the Canadarm2 robotic arm to move around the @Space_Station during today's spacewalk: https://t.co/J3tO3CP6Uk
name: NASA

text: @NurseyHappy Hello Eleanor! Temps on spacewalks can vary from -250° F to as hot as 250° in sunlight. For the astronauts, the temp change feeling is slight. Their suit's life support system provides a constant atmosphere providing comfort & protecting them from extremes of orbital day & night.
name: NASA

text: @DennisDMcDonald The antenna being replaced is quite old — it flew to the space station almost 21 years ago! It was steady and doing well until the last checkout this September, so it has been working for a very long time. Experts explained during a spacewalk preview: https://t.co/bb9CGNuWTz
name: NASA

text: @jpatt_k While they don't have planned leisure time during a spacewalk, there may be moments where they are instructed to wait — giving them an opportunity to observe the stars or the Earth below. @AstroDrewMorgan describes the view here: https://t.co/GMyIlbB907
name: NASA

text: ✅ Task complete! @AstroMarshburn and Kayla Barron successfully removed a failed S-band antenna from the @Space_Station's P-1 truss. Next, they'll stow it and retrieve the spare antenna for installation. https://t.co/PuTApMCNIs
name: NASA

text: @ksc1955 They can spacewalk as often as the replenishment of consumables can be accommodated like water and oxygen. Typically, we try to time spacewalks for 6.5 hours. The current record for the longest space station spacewalk was in 2001 & lasted 8 hrs, 56 minutes.
name: NASA

text: Spacewalk officially underway! At 6:15am ET, @AstroMarshburn & Kayla Barron of @NASA_Astronauts set their spacesuits to battery power, marking the start of a spacewalk expected to last about 6.5 hours. Watch live & send your questions using #AskNASA: https://t.co/CuuxMqEW9U
name: NASA

text: @stevenmwright Yes, mission managers found in mid-September that the @Space_Station had a degraded S-band assembly, allowing #Crew3's @AstroMarshburn & Kayla Barron time to practice the spacewalk to replace it before their launch. Experts explained in a news briefing: https://t.co/vMGkNdVRAO
name: NASA

text:

The spacewalk to replace an antenna system is expected to begin at ~7:10am ET and last ~6.5 hours. https://t.co/CuuxMqEW9U

text:
In a nearby galaxy, a supermassive black hole spews spectacular jets of material into space well beyond the galaxy’s limits.

What's going on?

text: RT @NASAUniverse : There’s hardly ever a dull day in the universe, especially when black holes are involved. ⚫ Check out this thread for some of the latest black hole news! #BlackHoleFriday https://t.co/V8XPTP4KIl
name: NASA

text:
Not all X-rays are the same!

Like other types of light, X-rays can have different polarizations—and when @NASA_Marshall's #IXPE observatory launches next month, it'll track polarized X-rays to help us study everything from black holes to pulsar winds: https://t.co/G1h1iyhZIU https://t.co/Pshkbe73ON
name: NASA

text:
When black holes collide, they could cause nearby material to radiate with light. A 2020 study made the first-ever observation of a flare that may have been produced when two smaller black holes merged to form a new, larger black hole: https://t.co/ign9NtsXc2

#BlackHoleFriday https://t.co/lRmUEe4bBB
name: NASA

text:

text:
How does a star’s light affect potential signs of life on planets that orbit it?

On Nov. 8, we're set to launch an experiment to see how starlight affects the atmospheres of planets circling stars other than our Sun — key info in the hunt for life: https://t.co/IPYwpdPWzB https://t.co/3VOWwLdGcx
name: NASA

text: @SFAA99409530 Yes! Scientists figured out that the bright areas were deposits made mostly of sodium carbonate, which likely came from liquid that percolated up to the surface. They concluded that the liquid came from a deep reservoir of brine, or salt-enriched water: https://t.co/C1zlZA7wAY
name: NASA

But quick question: What even is a nebula?

text: @dccampfin @NASAKennedy Yes! Lucy will perform two gravity assists to help get the spacecraft out to the Trojan asteroids in the Lagrange point 4 swarm. A final gravity assist will send Lucy on course to its culminating Trojan encounters in the Lagrange point 5 swarm.

text: @AstronautPip The first three asteroids discovered were given names after characters of The Iliad. As astronomers found more asteroids, they continued to be named after heroes from the Trojan War. ☄️ Find out more: https://t.co/vgGZLl3CoG

text: @AstronautPip @NASAKennedy The mission takes its name from the fossilized human ancestor (called “Lucy” by her discoverers) whose skeleton provided unique insight into humanity's evolution. Likewise, the Lucy mission will revolutionize our knowledge of planetary origins & the formation of the solar system.
name: NASA

text: @MikeBuzzNeil Lucy will use its terminal tracking camera (T2CAM) to help navigate & track asteroids during encounters. T2CAM will keep the asteroids in the main instruments' field of view & take wide-field images: https://t.co/iDLraK3Sxs When Lucy gets closer we could see tiny moons or rings!
name: NASA

text: @MikeBuzzNeil Great questions! It's important to remember that, in reality, these asteroids are extremely far apart from one another. In fact, if you were to stand on top of one asteroid and look out 360 degrees in every direction, you would not even see another asteroid.
name: NASA

name: NASA

name: NASA

name: NASA

text: RT @nasahqphoto : Liftoff of a @ULALaunch Atlas V rocket with the #Landsat 9 satellite onboard from Vandenberg Space Force Base in California! Landsat 9 continues a nearly 50-year legacy of observing Earth's landscapes and coastal regions. 📷https://t.co/PvP7MA6S21 https://t.co/5pzPfJ1kP5
name: NASA

text: The #Landsat 9 observatory has successfully separated and is on its way to continue 50 years of uninterrupted Earth observations 🌏👀 https://t.co/TqjP4ZGOLu
name: NASA

text:
"This record helps us understand not only that [climate] change is happening, but how fast, & whether it's accelerating — and what it means for humans."

Karen St. Germain, @NASAEarth Director, explains how #Landsat 9 helps us monitor the effects of climate change on our planet. https://t.co/6njZPWLP5g
name: NASA

text:
"The biggest challenge for this project has been trying to bring this mission to launch in the middle of a pandemic... and this team has just rallied."

Project Manager Del Jenstrom explains the challenges the #Landsat 9 team faced before reaching the launchpad today. https://t.co/6hiDG3ovkR
name: NASA

text:
"#Landsat is the longest continuous global satellite record of the Earth's surface. It helps farmers & scientists understand and manage land resources, and all of that is needed to sustain human life."

Administrator @SenBillNelson reflects on the significance of today's launch: https://t.co/CRZmRlPJNP
name: NASA

text: Enjoy this beautiful shot of the booster falling away after the booster engine cut off and separated from the #Landsat 9 payload 😍 https://t.co/eSvrJoKAZN
name: NASA

text:
And... liftoff! 🚀

The #Landsat 9 satellite has lifted off from the Vandenberg Space Force Base in California aboard a @ULALaunch Atlas V rocket at 2:12pm ET. https://t.co/O6YXhtf7kT
name: NASA

text: Through years of research, development, and testing, Virginia Norwood created the multispectral scanner system that flew on the very first #Landsat satellite and is considered the mother of the Earth-observing satellite series. 🛰️ https://t.co/HYWVUtRGYt
name: NASA

text:
"The way I think about it is that it's almost like a painting. Our research is the paint. Our #Landsat is the canvas." 

@Dr_ThomasZ, Associate Administrator of NASA Science, illustrates how important today's Earth satellite launch is. 🎨 https://t.co/H4qDEo4BCK
name: NASA

text:
"The #Landsat has been in existence for the last 50 years, and the technology gets better and better each time. This is such a rich form of data." 

Deb Haaland, Secretary of the Department of the @Interior, marvels at how today's launch will add to a treasure trove of data: https://t.co/ddPI6vGTNu
name: NASA

text:
"The full culmination of what it means to be at this stage in the game, ready to launch, is so remarkable... it's legitimately inspiring."

Actor Marc Evan Jackson, who played Landsat Steve in Kong: Skull Island, comments on the #Landsat legacy: https://t.co/ElRy7XGvot
name: NASA

text:
Today's launch of #Landsat 9 continues an uninterrupted stream of data about our home planet since 1972. This data helps world leaders: 

🌽Manage agriculture 
🚰Allocate water resources
🌪️Respond to natural disasters https://t.co/mGS0NLHl8M
name: NASA

text: ✔️ Astronauts @Aki_Hoshide and @Thom_Astro are back in the airlock, having concluded the 12th spacewalk of the year at 3:09pm ET (19:09 UT). The duo burned somewhere between 1,500 and 3,000 calories during their 6-hour and 54-minute excursion today. 🏋️‍♂️ https://t.co/kqhbemzBwV

name: NASA

text: @KAILASHH_94 Good question! Astronauts use pens aboard the @Space_Station because the lead in pencils could break off and become hazardous.
name: NASA

text: Here's how you twist wire ties with bulky spacesuit gloves. Now you know for when you find yourself on a spacewalk. 🤓 https://t.co/rOy1CSGNpV
name: NASA

text: @kuru_kittokuru Good evening! During orbital daytime, temperatures can get very hot, but astronauts are protected by their spacesuits. The outer layer is white so that it reflects heat, and astronauts also wear a cooling garment inside the suit to regulate temperatures during a spacewalk.
name: NASA

text: @NZCMeow Great question! Today’s spacewalk by @JAXA_jp & @ESA astronauts is designated as a U.S. spacewalk because it is conducted from the U.S. segment of the @Space_Station: the Quest airlock. It’s the first spacewalk by two of our international partner astronauts from the U.S. segment.
name: NASA

text: RT @ISS_Research : The VR camera capturing today’s spacewalk was specially designed to withstand the harsh environment of space.🎥 These filming activities test this type of camera for capturing future space activities. text: A look at the worksite from @Thom_Astro's helmet camera, as he & @Aki_Hoshide work to install a support bracket to enable future upgrades to the @Space_Station's solar arrays. Jessica Watkins of @NASA_Astronauts is communicating with the two spacewalkers from Mission Control. https://t.co/NUSwyGHA4S
name: NASA

text: @ksc1955 The spacewalk can last for as long as the replenishment of consumables, like water and oxygen, can be accommodated. Spacewalks are typically planned to last approximately 6.5 hours; the consumables could keep them out for up to 2 hours longer.
name: NASA

https://t.co/0u0PkLgtN1 #Roddenberry100

text:

text:
RT @NASAhistory : Happy Birthday to the iconic Gene Kranz! 

Kranz joined NASA in 1960 as the assistant flight director for Project Mercury. He went on to assume flight director duties for Project Gemini and was selected as division chief for Flight Control in 1968. https://t.co/5ONwU7HLNY
name: NASA

text:

name: NASA

text: ☄️ Comets usually contain ice, which vaporizes to give them their bright tail trailing behind. Asteroids are different — having little to no ice content. However, they can exhibit comet-like qualities. Find out why: https://t.co/xas2mdsqgy https://t.co/yjtgy5e65Y
name: NASA

text: @MassiPerro Astronauts need to ride in the same spacecraft for launch and return to and from the space station. The Crew-2 quartet needs to be aboard in the unlikely event it’s unable to redock. This assures there aren’t more crewmembers on the station than seats on docked crew ships.

text: @ExplosiveCat @Space_Station They can spacewalk as often as the replenishment of consumables can be accommodated like water and oxygen! Typically, we try to time spacewalks for 6.5 hours. The consumables could keep them out for up to 2 hours longer than that.

text:
The Moonikin riding aboard the #Artemis I mission will be vital to understanding what future astronauts will experience on the flight. But the Moonikin is missing something very important — a name! 
 
Head over to @NASAArtemis for a chance to vote: https://t.co/uarwcbC9Po https://t.co/4V0eu6PJGl
name: NASA

text: RT @Space_Station : .@NASA astronaut Shane Kimbrough and @ESA astronaut Thomas Pesquet concluded their spacewalk at 3:26 pm ET, after 7 hrs and 15 min. They installed a new ISS Roll-Out Solar Array into its mounting bracket and will continue the installation on June 20. https://t.co/BlTOB34IaP
name: NASA

text:
🙌 That’s a wrap! @Astro_Kimbrough & @Thom_Astro laid the groundwork for installation of the 1st pair of ISS Roll-Out Solar Arrays & head back into the @Space_Station.

Join us on June 20 at 6:30am ET (10:30 UT) for the duo's 2nd spacewalk to continue installing the new arrays: https://t.co/4XIiV8BRTV
name: NASA

text: Update: Due to technical delays earlier in the day, the spacewalkers will not have enough time to fully install the first pair of new, roll-up solar arrays on the @Space_Station. Stay tuned for more info! https://t.co/fBiUNvfQGL
name: NASA

text: @Heartie1990 Yes! We have been slowly upgrading the SD cameras on the @Space_station as well as the astronauts’ helmet cameras to HD. We agree the views are fantastic! https://t.co/7n3e9UzViC
name: NASA

text: The new, roll-up solar arrays have made it to their final destination. Next up? @Thom_Astro and @Astro_Kimbrough install them into a mounting bracket for rotating and unfolding. https://t.co/Jh3IJgrjaF
name: NASA

text: RT @Space_Station : A view of @ESA astronaut @Thom_astro, holding the 750 lb iROSA solar array, attached to the @csa_asc Canadarm operated by @NASA astronaut @Astro_Megan. https://t.co/cBNqC5JGaz https://t.co/hyLXwd9nw2
name: NASA

text: Safety first! @Astro_Kimbrough is back at the worksite after a reboot of his spacesuit's display unit, and a potential sensor error that has stabilized. The spacewalk continues. https://t.co/oH5P7s30fw
name: NASA

text: @CarterdotPur Spacewalking astronauts face a variety of temperatures. In Earth orbit, conditions can be as cold as minus 250 degrees Fahrenheit (minus 121 degrees Celsius). In the sunlight, they can be as hot as 250 degrees Fahrenheit (121 degrees Celsius).
name: NASA

text: Rest assured @Astro_Kimbrough is in no danger. Listen in for more updates from Mission Control: https://t.co/eMs9gtqjHR
name: NASA

text: Update: Ground teams are working a technical issue with @Astro_Kimbrough’s spacesuit causing the spacewalking duo to take a pause from releasing the ISS Roll-Out Solar Array (iROSAs) from their carrier. https://t.co/3oEuU3jEOL
name: NASA

text: @SukhpreeetKaur The eight current arrays are capable of generating up to 160 kilowatts of power during orbital daytime. Each new solar array will produce more than 20 kilowatts of electricity, eventually totaling 120 kilowatts (120,000 watts) of augmented power during orbital daytime!
name: NASA

text: @TheEaglePower Most of the station's oxygen comes from a process called "electrolysis," which uses electricity from the @Space_Station solar panels to split water into hydrogen gas and oxygen gas: https://t.co/VmYjOFb7q0
name: NASA

text: Have questions about today's spacewalk? We're here to help! Submit them using #AskNASA. https://t.co/cMfUqI1UNC
name: NASA

text: @geekycow Hello and thanks for the question, Julie. These dots you see are dead pixels from the camera, likely an effect of solar radiation!
name: NASA

text: An amazing view of @Thom_Astro using a Pistol Grip Tool (PGT) to break bolts on the carrier housing the @Space_Station's new solar arrays. @Astro_Kimbrough is at a different worksite routing harnesses for a future task. https://t.co/3iUUbCNqQ2
name: NASA

text:
Over one hour into today’s spacewalk, our astronauts are preparing to release the @Space_Station’s new, roll-up solar arrays from their carrier and move them to their installation site. 

📺 Watch the action LIVE from space: https://t.co/CKRBRGYf87
name: NASA

text: @Rajdeep_Luthra Thanks for the question! The original arrays will still be used, but they've degraded a little bit over their 20-year life span. The new ones will restore power generation to when the original arrays were installed.
name: NASA

text: @KDasgupta_18 Spacewalks are usually planned for 6-7 hours to get work done while they have enough power, oxygen, etc. With prep + clean up, it's a long day! The current record for longest @Space_Station spacewalk was in 2001 & lasted 8 hrs, 56 min: https://t.co/j6qW2xO8Qh
name: NASA

text: @RaffaeleDiPalma The arrays unfurl automatically once a pair of bolts are released as shown here: https://t.co/lysMkkYGxI. There is no motor or “on” switch to hit. Once those bolts are undone, the arrays will use stored energy to unroll. Once deployed, they'll stay in that configuration.
